intro: Sisyrinchium depauperatum, commonly known as the poorflower or slender blue-eyed grass, is a small, herbaceous perennial native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Poaceae, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, showy blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its flowers are clustered in spikelets, and it produces small, wind-dispersed seeds. Sisyrinchium depauperatum is adapted to arid environments and is often found in regions with well-drained soils.
